sections.title: Save painful teeth with calm, precise endodontics
sections.body: Modern root canal treatment removes infection, protects the tooth structure, and keeps your bite stable with minimal fuss.
bullets: Clear diagnosis to confirm when a root canal is the safest option
Gentle, well-anaesthetised care with careful rubber dam isolation
Restorations that seal the tooth and reduce the risk of reinfection

sections.title: Signs a tooth may need endodontic care
items: Lingering hot or cold sensitivity that doesn’t settle quickly
Spontaneous or night pain that radiates to the jaw or ear
Swelling, tenderness, or a pimple on the gum near the tooth
Cracks, deep decay, or a failing filling that has reached the nerve
Pain when biting that suggests nerve inflammation or infection
sections.strapline: If pain escalates rapidly or swelling spreads, contact us urgently — emergency dentistry support is available.

sections.title: Choose the right endodontic pathway
items: Assessment and pain relief for urgent toothache or swelling (/treatments/emergency-dentistry)
Primary root canal treatment to clear infection and stabilise the tooth (/treatments/endodontics-root-canal)
Retreatment or surgical referral when anatomy or previous work needs advanced care (discussed during assessment)
Extraction planning if a tooth cannot be predictably saved, with replacement routes explained (/treatments/extractions-and-oral-surgery)

sections.title: Step-by-step, focused on comfort
items: Assessment: X-rays or CBCT review to map canals and confirm diagnosis
Comfort: Local anaesthetic and rubber dam isolation keep the area dry and calm
Cleaning: Rotary instruments and irrigation remove inflamed or infected tissue
Shaping: Canal shaping with apex location for an accurate working length
Medication & sealing: Disinfection with medicaments then biocompatible filling
Restoration: A sealed filling or crown to protect the tooth from future fracture
Review: Follow-up to monitor healing and confirm symptoms have settled

sections.title: Digital diagnostics for predictable outcomes
sections.body: CBCT imaging, electronic apex location, and rotary endodontic systems guide the shape and depth of treatment, reducing guesswork and protecting surrounding bone and nerves.
sections.mediaHint: CBCT mapping, rotary instruments, and apex location

sections.title: Keeping you comfortable during and after treatment
items: Local anaesthetic throughout; sedation dentistry can be discussed for anxious patients
Gentle isolation and irrigation to minimise post-appointment tenderness
Clear guidance on eating, cleaning, and managing expected soreness
Advice on temporary restorations if a crown is planned
Follow-up to confirm the tooth is settling and the bite feels balanced

sections.title: Honest guidance before we start
sections.body: We explain the chances of complex anatomy, existing cracks, or reinfection and when retreatment, surgical endodontics, or extraction may be safer. You’ll know the backup plan before consenting.
bullets: Discusses structural strength and whether a crown is needed
Explains limits of heavily cracked or previously treated teeth
Outlines alternatives such as monitoring, extraction, or implant replacement
Clear consent and documentation with realistic expectations

sections.title: Protecting the tooth for the long term
sections.body: Well-sealed canals and a protective restoration keep success rates high. We review healing radiographically and discuss maintenance to preserve the tooth for years.
bullets: Most treated teeth remain comfortable and functional for many years
Bite checks reduce the risk of fractures after treatment
Regular hygiene visits help prevent reinfection from new decay
If a tooth cannot be saved, we’ll plan extractions and future implant or bridge options

faqs.question: Will a root canal hurt?
faqs.answer: Treatment is carried out under local anaesthetic with careful isolation. Most patients feel pressure rather than pain, and any post-treatment tenderness usually settles with simple pain relief.

faqs.question: How long does it take?
faqs.answer: Many cases are completed in one to two visits depending on the number of canals and whether we need to place medication between appointments.

faqs.question: Do I always need a crown afterwards?
faqs.answer: Back teeth or heavily restored teeth often benefit from a crown to prevent fractures. We will explain the best way to seal and protect your tooth.

faqs.question: What if the tooth can’t be saved?
faqs.answer: We will outline alternatives such as extraction with healing guidance and future replacement options like bridges or implants if appropriate.

sections.title: Need relief from tooth pain?
sections.body: Book an endodontic assessment so we can calm the tooth, protect your smile, and plan any follow-up care together.
